oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Advertisement for a Vanderbilt Theatre production of an orginal play by Brainerd Cheney, "I Choose to Die: the Story of Sam Davis."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides; Rebellions; War; Theatrical posters; Theatrical productions
Broadsides; Davis, Sam, 1842-1863; Drama ; United States - History - Drama; Civil War, U. S., 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Vanderbilt University
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Brainard Cheney was a novelist, playwright, political speechwriter, and essayist. He became associated with the Agrarian movement as a student at Vanderbilt. He wrote Gov. Frank Clement's address at the 1956 Democratic National Convention ("How long oh Lord, how long..."), as well as assisting Robert Penn Warren with some of the speeches in his novel, "All the King's Men." He and his wife, Frances Neel Cheney (a grandniece of Sam Davis), lived in Smyrna, Tennessee.
